Any other candidate being selected will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

While it's not unprecedented for outsiders to secure major party nominations, the likelihood remains low without a formal campaign announcement and demonstrated political momentum.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare a sitting president incapacitated is an unprecedented and highly significant action that requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to formally agree that the president is unable to discharge the duties of the office. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been no substantial evidence or credible reports suggesting that Vice President Kamala Harris or the current Cabinet have expressed intentions to pursue such a course of action against President Joe Biden. Additionally, political dynamics, party loyalty, and the potential for severe constitutional and political repercussions make the likelihood of initiating Section 4 invocation extremely low. Historical precedent and the seriousness of the amendment's use further diminish the probability of this event occurring within the specified timeframe.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has not made any definitive public announcements indicating that he will not seek re-election as the Democratic Party's nominee for the 2024 Presidential election. Historically, incumbent presidents typically run for a second term unless significant personal or political factors lead them to decide otherwise. While President Biden's age (he would be in his early 80s during the 2024 election) and potential political challenges could influence his decision, there has been no clear indication from him or his campaign suggesting an intention to step aside. Given the lack of any official statements or strong signals from Biden or his team about not pursuing the nomination, it is unlikely that such an announcement will be made before July 15, 2024.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 and (b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count. Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Invoking the 25th Amendment Section 4 to declare a sitting president incapacitated is an exceedingly rare and politically charged action. Historically, it has never been successfully used, and doing so would require significant consensus among the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet or relevant officials. As of the latest information up to October 2023, there are no substantial indicators or ongoing efforts within the administration or the Cabinet to pursue such a declaration against President Biden.

Simultaneously, for President Biden to publicly announce by July 15, 2024, that he will not seek the Democratic nomination would represent a major shift in his political trajectory. Given his ongoing administration activities, policy initiatives, and the lack of any definitive statements from Biden or his campaign indicating an intention to step down, this scenario appears highly unlikely.

The combination of both events occurring within the specified timeframe is therefore extremely improbable, considering the legal, political, and personal factors involved.

question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if either of the following occurs:

(a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office," causing the Vice President to serve as Acting President. The duration of the incapacity does not matter. Biden exiting the office by death, resignation, etc., does not count. Biden invoking Section 3 of the 25th Amendment does not count.

(b) Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, stating that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility of accepting the nomination.

If either condition (a) or (b) is met, this question resolves as **Yes**.

Such a declaration requires a collective decision by the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet, which is an unlikely scenario without clear evidence of incapacity. Additionally, there were no public statements or trends indicating that Biden intended to decline the Democratic nomination for the 2024 presidential election. While political landscapes can change, the probability of either condition (a) or (b) occurring before mid-July 2024 remains low based on available information.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Considering the current political landscape, the Democratic Party is likely to coalesce around a single candidate for the 2024 presidential election, especially if the incumbent seeks re-election. Historically, major parties rarely experience brokered conventions, and there hasn't been significant indication of a fractured Democratic field that would necessitate multiple voting rounds. Additionally, party leadership and primary processes are designed to streamline the nomination to prevent such scenarios. Therefore, the probability of Democrats having a brokered convention in 2024 is low.

Incumbent presidents often benefit from the advantages of office, including greater visibility and the ability to influence the national agenda. Additionally, FiveThirtyEight's polling methodologies have consistently provided reliable aggregations that reflect broader voter sentiments. While political dynamics can change significantly over time due to factors such as economic shifts, policy decisions, and unforeseen events, there is no substantial evidence to suggest a strong surge in Trump's polling numbers that would specifically place his lead within the 3 to 4-point range by July 15, 2024. Therefore, the likelihood of Trump's lead over Biden falling between greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 in FiveThirtyEight's national polling average on the specified date appears to be relatively low.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Larry Elder is a well-known conservative commentator who has considered running for the Republican nomination in the 2024 US Presidential Election. However, as of the latest information available up to October 2023, he has not established a significant campaign infrastructure or garnered widespread support comparable to leading candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley. The Republican field is competitive, and established figures typically have advantages in fundraising, name recognition, and delegate support. Additionally, Larry Elder's campaign efforts have not shown substantial traction in primary polls or endorsements that would position him as a frontrunner. Given these factors, it is unlikely that he will secure the nomination at the Republican National Convention.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average (b) Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for the purposes of this question.

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future. For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:
For both (a) and (b) to occur, Donald Trump must have a lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average between 3 and 4 points on July 15, 2024, and Larry Elder must secure the Republican nomination for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

However, these two events are highly dependent and mutually exclusive in the current political landscape. Donald Trump is a leading figure within the Republican Party and is widely regarded as the frontrunner for the Republican nomination. Larry Elder, while a recognized conservative commentator, has not demonstrated similar traction or support within the party to realistically secure the nomination over Trump. 

If Larry Elder were to become the Republican nominee (event b), it is unlikely that Donald Trump would maintain a lead over Joe Biden in the national polling average, as the Republican support base would likely consolidate behind the official nominee rather than split between multiple candidates. Therefore, the occurrence of (b) would significantly diminish the probability of (a) happening.

Considering the current political dynamics and the dependencies between these two events, the probability that both (a) and (b) occur is extremely low.

(a) **Trump's Polling Lead:** As of the latest data before the knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Donald Trump has maintained a significant lead in Republican primary polls, making him a frontrunner for the nomination. question.title: Will the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee be a Woman?
question.body:

Will resolve “no” if/when the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the Democratic field for the 2024 Presidential nomination is primarily composed of male candidates who have established significant support and recognition within the party. Prominent female figures such as Vice President Kamala Harris, Senator Elizabeth Warren, and others have not yet officially declared their candidacies or, in some cases, have indicated limited interest in running. While there is a growing emphasis on gender diversity within the Democratic Party, historical trends and the current state of the primary race suggest that a female nominee is less likely at this time. However, political dynamics can change rapidly, and emerging candidates or shifts in voter sentiment could influence the outcome.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, voleyball and water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has historically demonstrated strong performances across multiple women's team sports, including association football, 5×5 basketball, 3×3 basketball, volleyball, and water polo. Additionally, countries like France and the Netherlands are competitive in several other team sports such as rugby sevens, handball, and field hockey. Given the depth and breadth of talent in these nations, it is highly probable that at least one nation will secure gold in more than one of the specified women's team sports at the 2024 Olympics.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) The 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee be a Woman (2) The same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
(1) The question about the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee will resolve “yes” if/when the Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election, and “no” if/when they select a male nominee.

(2) The question about the 2024 Olympics will resolve as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, it resolves as Yes if the same NOC wins at least two of these events.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that both (1) the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee will be a woman and (2) the same nation will win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics, we need to assess each event individually and then consider their combined likelihood.

1. **2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee Being a Woman**: Historically, the Democratic Party has not yet nominated a female presidential candidate, though there has been increasing support and prominent female figures within the party, such as Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris. The momentum for female candidates is growing, but breaking the historical precedent is challenging. Given the current political landscape and the competitiveness of the nomination process, there is a moderate chance that the nominee could be a woman.

2. **Same Nation Winning Multiple Women's Team Sports at the 2024 Olympics**: Typically, certain nations dominate women's team sports at the Olympics, with the United States, for example, having strong programs in sports like basketball, soccer, and volleyball. It's common for a dominant country to secure multiple gold medals across different team sports due to their established training programs and resources. Therefore, it is likely that the same nation will win more than one women's team sport.

Assuming these two events are relatively independent, we can estimate their individual probabilities and then calculate the joint probability:
- Probability of a female Democratic nominee: ~60%
- Probability of the same nation winning multiple women's team sports: ~70%

Combined Probability: 0.6 * 0.7 = 0.42

question.body:
(a) Will the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee be a Woman? This will resolve “yes” if/when the Democratic delegates select a female presidential nominee for the 2024 election. It will resolve “no” if/when the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election.

(b) Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics? This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, volleyball, and water polo. Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as Yes.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The overall question resolves to 'Yes' if either (a) the 2024 Democratic Presidential Nominee is a woman or (b) the same nation wins more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics. For part (a), while there are prominent female candidates such as Kamala Harris and Elizabeth Warren, the Democratic nomination process is highly competitive and it's uncertain whether a female candidate will secure the nomination. This estimates a moderate probability of around 40% for part (a). For part (b), historically, certain nations like the United States have dominated multiple women's team sports in the Olympics. Given the competitive landscape and the strengths of established teams, it's highly likely that one nation will win more than one women's team sport. This estimates a high probability of around 90% for part (b). Since the overall question resolves to 'Yes' if either part (a) or part (b) is true, and part (b) has a high likelihood of occurring, the combined probability that at least one of the two events occurs is very high.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has not made any definitive announcements regarding his intention to seek re-election in the 2024 presidential race. Unless unforeseen circumstances arise or clear signals are given, it is expected that Biden may continue to position himself for a re-election campaign.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Democratic Party has a substantial number of members in both the House and Senate, making it feasible to gather at least 20 signatures opposing the early virtual nomination of President Biden. The context provided indicates that there is organized opposition within the party, with Rep. Jared Huffman actively involved in drafting a letter and multiple House Democrats expressing concerns. Given the existing dissent and the strategic importance of the nomination process, it is likely that the opposition will mobilize enough support to meet the threshold. Additionally, the ability to aggregate signatures across multiple letters rather than relying on a single document further increases the probability of achieving the required number of signatories.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, incumbent President Joe Biden is running for re-election as the Democratic nominee for the 2024 U.S. presidential election. Historically, incumbent presidents with strong party support secure their party's nomination on the first ballot during the convention, thereby avoiding a brokered convention. Brokered conventions, where no single candidate obtains a majority on the first ballot and multiple rounds of voting are necessary, are rare in recent U.S. political history. Given President Biden's established position within the Democratic Party and the absence of significant primary challengers that could jeopardize his nomination, it is highly unlikely that the Democratic National Convention will be brokered in 2024.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking the 25th Amendment Section 4 to declare a sitting president incapacitated is a significant and unprecedented action in U.S. history. This process requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or another designated body) to formally declare that the president is unable to discharge the duties of the office. Historically, this section has never been used. Additionally, such a move would likely face substantial political resistance and require clear evidence of incapacity, neither of which are evident based on available information up to October 2023. While there may be political motivations behind GOP lawmakers urging for its invocation, the actual likelihood of successfully declaring President Biden incapacitated before August 2024 remains low.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden, the incumbent president, and Donald Trump, a prominent challenger, are the primary contenders for the 2024 US presidential election. FiveThirtyEight's election forecasts consider various factors, including approval ratings, economic indicators, historical trends, and polling data. Up to October 2023, Biden's approval ratings have shown moderate stability, while Trump's candidacy has maintained a strong base of support. Economic conditions, policy successes or challenges, and significant national or global events between October 2023 and July 19, 2024, will heavily influence the forecast. If Biden manages to improve his approval ratings and address key policy areas effectively, FiveThirtyEight may project him as the favorite. Conversely, any decline in his support or significant positive developments for Trump could tilt the forecast in Trump's favor. Given the uncertainties and the competitive nature of the upcoming election, it's difficult to assign a high probability to either candidate without updated data closer to the resolution date.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, and (b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
(a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024: Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024: This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19. Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is exceedingly low. Invoking Section 4 requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to unanimously agree that the President is unable to perform his duties, a step that has never been taken in modern U.S. history and would likely only occur under severe and unprecedented circumstances. Concurrently, FiveThirtyEight projecting Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024, is plausible given his incumbency and typical advantages held by sitting presidents in elections, assuming no drastic negative shifts in public opinion or unforeseen events. However, the simultaneous occurrence of these two events is virtually negligible, as the first event's rarity overwhelmingly diminishes the likelihood of both happening together.

question.body:
This question resolves to YES if either of the following occurs:

(a) Biden is declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. This occurs if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invoke Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc., does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

(b) FiveThirtyEight projects Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024. This occurs if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Thus, if either (a) or (b) is true, the answer to this question will be YES.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Declaring a sitting U.S. president incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 is a highly complex and unprecedented action that requires substantial consensus among the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet. Historically, this has never been successfully invoked, making scenario (a) extremely unlikely barring any unforeseen and severe circumstances affecting President Biden's ability to perform his duties. On the other hand, FiveThirtyEight's projection of Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024, hinges on his performance in ongoing elections, polling data, and overall campaign momentum. If Biden maintains a competitive edge in the polls leading up to that date, it is plausible that FiveThirtyEight would project him as the favorite. Given that scenario (b) is relatively more probable than scenario (a), and considering that the two events are mutually exclusive, the combined probability that either event occurs is primarily driven by the likelihood of scenario (b).

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question may consider new candidates added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Donald Trump remains a highly influential figure within the Republican Party. His strong base of support and previous experience as the party's nominee in 2016 and 2020 position him as a leading candidate for the 2024 nomination. While there are emerging contenders such as Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley who are gaining traction, Trump's established presence and continued popularity among a significant portion of Republican voters suggest that he is likely to secure the nomination. However, the dynamic nature of political races means that unforeseen events or shifts in voter sentiment could impact the outcome. Considering these factors, there is a high probability that Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no single candidate secures a majority of delegates during the primary elections, necessitating additional rounds of voting to determine the nominee. In the 2024 Democratic Party context, incumbent President Joe Biden is seeking re-election. Historically, incumbent presidents running for a second term within their party face minimal primary challenges, as the party typically rallies around the sitting president to present a united front. Unless a significant and widespread movement emerges within the Democratic Party to challenge Biden's renomination, it is unlikely that the convention will require multiple ballots. Given the advantage incumbents generally hold and the lack of prominent contenders as of the latest information available, the probability of the Democratic Party having a brokered convention in 2024 is very low.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

Jared Huffman has publicly criticized the Democratic National Committee's decision and mentioned the planning to speak out against the early nomination, suggesting that there is momentum behind this opposition. Although Rep. Huffman declined to confirm the existence of an official letter, the fact that Politico obtained a draft circulated by Huffman and that multiple members are involved implies that reaching the threshold of 20 signatories is plausible. Additionally, the timeline until the market closes on July 21st provides sufficient time for more Democrats to join the effort. Taking these factors into account, it is likely that at least 20 House or Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the early nomination plan.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

question.title: Iran military response before August 13th midnight Eastern Time?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Iran initiates a military action on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory between July 30 and August 12, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

For the purposes of this market, a "military action" will be considered to be any use of force executed by Iran on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory (e.g. if a weapons depot on Israeli soil is hit by an Iranian missile, this market will resolve to "Yes") that is officially acknowledged by the Iranian government or a consensus of credible reporting. This includes, but is not limited to, airstrikes, naval attacks, or ground invasions. Cyber attacks, sanctions, or diplomatic actions will not count towards the resolution of this market.

Only responses by Iranian forces explicitly claimed by the Islamic Republic of Iran, or confirmed to have originated from Iranian territory will count toward the resolution of this market. Attacks on Israel by proxy forces (i.e. Hezbollah, Houthis, etc.) will not count toward the resolution of this market.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the relationship between Iran and Israel has been tense, with ongoing proxy conflicts primarily in regions like Syria and Lebanon through groups such as Hezbollah. While both nations have engaged in hostile rhetoric and actions, the likelihood of direct military confrontation remains relatively low due to the potential for significant regional destabilization and the risk of broader conflict involving major powers. Additionally, both Iran and Israel possess substantial military capabilities, which serve as a deterrent against direct attacks. However, sporadic escalations cannot be entirely ruled out given the volatile nature of Middle Eastern geopolitics. Considering these factors, the probability of Iran initiating a direct military action on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory between July 30 and August 12, 2024, is relatively low.

2. **Iran Initiating Military Action on Israeli Territory:** While Iran and Israel have longstanding tensions, direct military action by Iran on Israeli soil would represent a significant escalation with serious regional and global repercussions. Such actions are generally deterred by the potential for severe retaliation, economic sanctions, and international condemnation. Although proxy conflicts and cyber operations have been more common, an overt military strike remains unlikely in the near term unless triggered by a major unforeseen event.

Considering the uncertainties and the independent nature of these two events, the probability that both occur before August 13, 2024, is relatively low.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, national polling averages from FiveThirtyEight have shown varying levels of support between Donald Trump and Joe Biden. Polling dynamics in the months leading up to a presidential election typically fluctuate due to numerous factors such as campaign events, policy announcements, current events, and public sentiment. Historically, leads in national polls can shift as the election approaches, but a lead within the range of 2 to 4 points is considered moderate and manageable. Assuming current trends continue and no significant events drastically alter voter preferences, it is plausible that on July 15, 2024, Trump's lead over Biden in FiveThirtyEight's national polling average will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 points.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: A brokered convention occurs when no single candidate secures a majority of delegates during the primary process, necessitating multiple rounds of voting to determine the nominee. As of October 2023, the Democratic Party has seen a diverse field of candidates with varying levels of support. If no candidate consolidates enough delegate support early on, and if multiple strong contenders emerge, the likelihood of a brokered convention increases. Historical precedents within the Democratic Party, although less common in recent cycles, indicate that brokered conventions are possible under certain conditions, such as a fragmented vote or the absence of a clear frontrunner. Additionally, changes in primary rules, delegate allocation methods, and the overall political climate leading up to the convention could influence the outcome. Given these factors, while there are mechanisms in place to avoid a brokered convention, the presence of multiple competitive candidates and the potential for shifting alliances make it a plausible scenario.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, and (2) Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body:
(1) Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average. This is based on Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead.

(2) The Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this condition is not met.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that both conditions occur, we need to evaluate each separately and then consider their joint likelihood.

1. **Trump's Lead over Biden on July 15, 2024:**
   - **Current Polling Trends:** As of October 2023, Donald Trump and Joe Biden are the primary contenders for their respective parties in the 2024 U.S. presidential election. While Trump maintains a significant base of support, Biden, as the incumbent, also has established advantages.
   - **538's National Polling Average:** FiveThirtyEight aggregates multiple polls to provide a national average. Given the volatile nature of political campaigns, it's challenging to predict exact leads this far in advance. However, a lead of greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 is a moderate range that is plausible but uncertain due to potential campaign dynamics, unforeseen events, and changing voter sentiments.

2. **Democrats Having a Brokered Convention in 2024:**
   - **Current Democratic Landscape:** Joe Biden, as the incumbent president, is the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. Historically, incumbent presidents seeking renomination face minimal opposition within their party.
   - **Likelihood of Multiple Candidates:** For a brokered convention to occur, there would need to be significant contention with multiple strong candidates failing to secure a majority of delegates. As of the latest information, there is no indication of substantial dissent within the Democratic Party that would lead to a brokered convention.

**Joint Probability Assessment:**
- **Independence Assumption:** The two events are largely independent. Trump's polling lead does not directly influence the Democratic nomination process and vice versa.
- **Probability Estimates:**
  - **Trump's Lead:** Considering the uncertainties, there's a moderate likelihood (around 40%) that Trump's lead falls within the specified range by July 15, 2024.
  - **Brokered Convention:** Given the incumbent status of Biden and the lack of significant opposition, the probability of a brokered convention is very low (around 5%).

- **Combined Probability:** Multiplying the individual probabilities (0.40 * 0.05) gives a joint probability of 0.02.

If only one ballot is required, this part resolves as **No**.

To estimate the probability that either (a) Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's national polling average for the 2024 presidential election is greater than 2 and less than or equal to 4 points on July 15, 2024, or (b) the Democratic Party has a brokered convention in 2024, we must assess both scenarios individually and consider their potential overlap.

For scenario (a), as of the latest polls leading up to mid-2024, political dynamics suggest that the race between Trump and Biden is competitive but fluctuates within a narrow margin. Historical polling data indicates that a lead of 2 to 4 points is within the realm of possibility, especially considering factors like economic performance, foreign policy developments, and campaign strategies. For scenario (b), the likelihood of a brokered Democratic convention depends on the primary contest's competitiveness. If the Democratic primaries yield a clear frontrunner with substantial support, a brokered convention becomes highly unlikely. However, if the primary race remains tightly contested with no candidate securing a majority of delegates, the probability of a brokered convention increases. Given the current state of the Democratic primaries, there appears to be a strong possibility of a clear nominee emerging without the need for multiple ballots.

Considering the two scenarios, while both are plausible independently, the convergence of both occurring simultaneously (i.e., Trump holding a specific polling lead while the Democrats experience a brokered convention) is relatively low. Therefore, the combined probability accounts for the likelihood of either event happening separately, minus the small chance of both occurring together.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Albania has been a consistent participant in the Eurovision Song Contest, often showcasing strong performances that resonate with both juries and the public. Historically, Albania has qualified for the Grand Final numerous times since its debut in 2004, with their best result being fifth place in 2012. While each year's competition varies in terms of participating countries, song quality, and staging, Albania typically invests significant effort in selecting entries that have broad appeal. Assuming Albania continues this trend in 2024 and considering their track record, it is reasonably likely they will secure a spot in the Grand Final. However, the outcome also depends on the competitiveness of other entries and voting dynamics, which introduce some uncertainty.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if both Georgia and Albania participate in a Semi-final and are officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. For any other outcome, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, both Georgia and Albania have participated in the Eurovision Song Contest with varying degrees of success. Georgia has qualified for the Grand Final multiple times since their debut in 2007, often showcasing strong vocal performances and memorable staging. Similarly, Albania has also made several appearances in the Grand Final since their return to the contest in 2004, though they have faced challenges in consistently securing a top position. For Eurovision 2024, factors that could influence their qualification include the quality and appeal of their selected songs, the performance execution, geopolitical voting patterns, and the overall competitiveness of other participating countries. Additionally, changes in the voting system or regional bloc voting dynamics could impact their chances. Considering these variables and aiming for a balanced assessment, there is a moderate likelihood that both Georgia and Albania will successfully qualify for the Grand Final.

question.title: Will either Georgia or Albania qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Georgia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, or (b) Albania participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. The question will resolve as **No** if neither Georgia nor Albania qualifies for the Grand Final.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Both Georgia and Albania have been consistent participants in the Eurovision Song Contest, each with varying degrees of success in qualifying for the Grand Final. Historically, Albania has had a slightly better track record, having reached the top 10 several times, while Georgia has also made notable entries but has faced challenges in securing a spot in the final more recently. The probability of either country qualifying this year depends on several factors, including the strength of their respective entries, the competitiveness of their semi-finals, and the overall voting trends. Given their historical performances and assuming they present strong entries for Eurovision 2024, it is reasonably likely that at least one of them will qualify for the Grand Final.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Public opinion polls indicate that Joe Biden is consistently trailing Donald Trump beyond the margin of error, whereas generic Democrats tend to either lead or are within the margin of error against Trump. This suggests that Trump performs better when facing Biden compared to when facing a generic Democrat. The significant difference in polling performance implies that Trump's vote share is likely to be at least 3% higher when facing Biden rather than a generic Democrat among Manifold respondents.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The current context indicates that two safe-seat Democratic House members have publicly urged President Biden to drop out, and two other vulnerable Democrats have expressed doubts about his re-election prospects. Additionally, there are reports of multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats, with at least one calling for Biden to end his campaign. However, for the market to resolve YES, a minimum of five named Democratic US House Members or Senators must collectively pressure Biden to drop out by July 20th. As of now, only two have publicly taken such a stance. While behind-the-scenes discussions and drafts suggest growing concern within the party, mobilizing five named members to publicly push for Biden's withdrawal within the specified timeframe is a significant escalation and may face internal party dynamics and loyalty considerations. Given these factors, the likelihood of meeting the threshold required for a YES resolution appears low but not impossible.

question.title: Will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden and will a group of at least 5 named Democrats pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met:

(a) There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6. One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot. This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close. The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03. Otherwise, it is NO.

(b) A group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time). This could be by signing a letter like what is reported, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out. This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution. Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO.

If both conditions (a) and (b) are satisfied, this question resolves YES. If either condition is not met, this question resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Evaluating the probability that Donald Trump gains at least a 3% advantage over Joe Biden among Manifold respondents involves considering several factors. Historically, Trump has maintained a strong and loyal base within the Republican Party, which could contribute to a competitive edge in polls. However, Joe Biden's incumbency and established policies may counterbalance this advantage. The specific threshold of a 3% gain is significant but not unprecedented, depending on current political climates, campaign strategies, and external events influencing voter sentiment.

Regarding the second condition, it requires at least five named Democratic Party members to publicly pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th. Historically, high-profile members of a party pressuring their own candidate to withdraw is relatively uncommon and could indicate significant internal dissent or challenges to Biden's candidacy. The feasibility of this happening depends on Biden's performance, public perception, and the political dynamics within the Democratic Party leading up to the specified date.

Both conditions need to be met for the question to resolve YES. Given the uncertainties surrounding voter behavior, campaign dynamics, and intra-party relations, while it's possible for Trump to achieve the required polling advantage and for a group of Democrats to publicly pressure Biden, these events would require specific and significant shifts in the current political landscape.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat, or (b) a group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
(a) Trump gains at least 3% among Manifold respondents facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat: There are two Manifold polls closing on July 6. One asks respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another with a generic Democrat. This will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Trump in the Biden poll exceeds the generic Democrat poll by 3% or more. The formula used is (Trump / (Trump + the Democrat + Someone else)) for each poll, and the difference must be >= 0.03 for a YES resolution.

(b) A group of at least 5 named Democratic House Members or Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th: This resolves YES if at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th, either by signing a letter or another form of collective request. All five must be part of the same group message. Reports of unnamed Democrats are insufficient unless names are made public before the end date.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that either (a) Trump gains at least a 3% advantage among Manifold respondents when facing Biden instead of a generic Democrat, or (b) a group of at least five named Democratic House Members or Senators pressures Biden to drop out before July 20th, we can analyze each scenario individually.

(a) **Trump's 3% Gain Among Manifold Respondents**: This outcome depends on voter behavior changes between facing a specific opponent (Biden) versus a generic Democrat. Factors influencing this could include Trump’s campaign strategies, current political events, and voter sentiment toward Biden. Historically, shifts of this magnitude in polling are notable but not unprecedented. If there are significant events or changes in voter sentiment close to the polling dates (e.g., major policy announcements, scandals, or shifts in the political landscape), a 3% swing is plausible. However, predicting such specific changes with high confidence is challenging.

(b) **Pressure from Democratic House Members or Senators on Biden**: For at least five named Democratic legislators to collectively urge President Biden to drop out of the race involves a significant breach of party unity. Such actions would likely indicate substantial dissatisfaction with Biden's performance or strategy. While intra-party disagreements are common, publicly pressuring the incumbent president to withdraw is rare and would require compelling circumstances. Unless there are emerging crises or widespread discontent within the Democratic caucus, this scenario remains unlikely.

Considering both scenarios, while a 3% polling shift is within the realm of possibility given certain conditions, the collective pressure from multiple Democratic legislators presents a more substantial hurdle and is less likely without extraordinary circumstances.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been significant discussion and legal debate regarding the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify Donald Trump from holding federal office due to the events of January 6, 2021. However, no federal or state court has definitively ruled to remove him from any primary election ballots under this provision. Implementing such a removal would likely require a combination of legal actions, including court rulings and official state decisions, which involve complex and potentially lengthy legal processes. Additionally, political factors and public opinion would play substantial roles in influencing any such decisions. Given these considerations and the lack of concrete legal precedents as of late 2023, the probability that Donald Trump will be officially removed or blocked from any state’s primary election ballot for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024, appears to be relatively low.

- **Cryptocurrency Engagement:** Given Musk's influence in the cryptocurrency space, his participation in a major Bitcoin conference is plausible. However, without a confirmed invitation or public statement, the certainty remains low.

**Condition (b): Donald Trump removed or blocked from primary election ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment**
- **Legal Framework:** Section 3 of the 14th Amendment addresses disqualification from holding office for individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion. Implementing this requires substantial legal and political processes, including court rulings and state-level actions.
- **Current Status:** As of October 2023, there have been no definitive legal actions or court decisions removing Donald Trump from primary ballots under this provision. Such a significant move would likely entail extensive legal battles, making the outcome uncertain and the likelihood relatively low.

**Combined Assessment:**
Even if condition (a) were to occur with moderate probability, the improbability of condition (b) being satisfied simultaneously significantly diminishes the overall likelihood of both conditions being met.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur after the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

(b) **Donald Trump’s Removal from a Primary Election Ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment**: Section 3 of the 14th Amendment prohibits individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding federal office. While there have been discussions and legal analyses regarding its applicability to Donald Trump, as of the knowledge cutoff in October 2023, no definitive legal action has been taken to remove him from any primary election ballots under this provision. Given the complexity and high threshold for such a removal, especially within the specified timeframe, this outcome appears unlikely.

question.title: Will Fidesz-KDNP Maintain Its EU Plurality from Hungary in 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve to "Yes" if, following the 2024 European Parliament elections, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance secures more seats than any other single party or coalition, thereby maintaining the highest number of Hungarian seats in the European Parliament, according to credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, the Fidesz-KDNP alliance remains the dominant political force in Hungary, consistently securing a significant majority in both national and European elections. Their strong organizational structure, loyal voter base, and effective leadership under Viktor Orbán have contributed to their sustained electoral success. While opposition parties have been making efforts to consolidate and challenge Fidesz-KDNP's dominance, no single opposition coalition has yet matched their level of organization or popular support. Additionally, Fidesz-KDNP's stance on key issues resonates with a substantial portion of the Hungarian electorate, further solidifying their position. Assuming there are no major political upheavals or significant shifts in public sentiment before the 2024 European Parliament elections, it is likely that Fidesz-KDNP will maintain its plurality in the EU Parliament from Hungary.

question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before July 5, 2024, credible sources report that the European Union (EU) has announced that new tariffs or duties will be imposed that would apply to imports of Chinese electric vehicles into the EU.

The EU generally prefers to engage in dialogue and negotiation rather than impose sudden trade barriers. The EU has been gradually moving towards stricter regulations on imports to protect its industries and address environmental concerns. However, given the broader EU consensus on certain trade and environmental policies, this interdependency might not heavily sway the overall probability.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought: The projections for "Deadpool x Wolverine" anticipate a global opening weekend between $340 million and $360 million, surpassing the previous R-rated movie record of $284.5 million. Domestically, the expected $160 million to $170 million also exceeds the existing record of $152.2 million. The combination of the strong fan bases for both Deadpool and Wolverine, along with increased theater placements, supports the likelihood of achieving these numbers. Additionally, the historical performance of the original Deadpool suggests a positive trend. However, factors such as competition from other major releases, market conditions, and actual audience turnout could influence the final outcome. Considering these aspects, there is a high probability that the movie will set a new record for an R-rated opening weekend.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, the Greens–EFA group has held a smaller proportion of seats in the European Parliament compared to larger political groups such as the European People’s Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). The EPP and S&D have consistently been the largest groups in previous European Parliamentary elections.
